head.title: Ruling on Coercion Strikes at Constitution

hedline.hl1: Ruling on Coercion Strikes at Constitution

block.p: In "High Court, 5 to 4, Softens Stand Against Confession by Coercion" (front page, March 27) you report the Supreme Court decision that declares the use of coerced confessions is "harmless error." This decision is an abomination.

In "High Court, 5 to 4, Softens Stand Against Confession by Coercion" (front page, March 27) you report the Supreme Court decision that declares the use of coerced confessions is "harmless error." This decision is an abomination.

The Court's rationale was that where other evidence exists to sustain guilt, the forced confession should not result in acquittal. But there will always be other evidence on which a conviction might be sustained; awareness of this will surely encourage the police to use coercion.
Coerced confessions are so repugnant to the Constitution and our mores that I just can't imagine condoning their use.
Furthermore, the Rehnquist Court claims to be guided by a strict-constructionist philosophy. Gratuitously overthrowing 40 years of consistent court rulings in this decision belies that claim.

There couldn't be a clearer case of judicial legislation than this decision or a more dangerous occasion of judicial intrusion. The constitutional fabric of the country is in grave jeopardy if the Supreme Court continues on this path. RICHARD L. OTTINGER Professor of Law, Pace University White Plains, April 10, 1991
